title: Families on housing benefit can’t afford to rent 94% of homes in England
text:
According to a recent study, the Bureau of Investigative Journalism, the majority of landlords in Britain would not rent properties to those on benefits (Picture: 2007 Getty)

Families who receive housing benefit can’t afford to rent 94 per cent of properties in England after the benefits freeze came into place, according to the National Housing Federation (NHF).

Low income families are being ‘pushed to the brink’, with those on Local Housing Allowance (LHA) only able to afford 7.5 per cent of the 75,000 private rental adverts analysed, the Federation said.

In some areas, less than 1 per cent of family homes, those with two or three bedrooms, were affordable.

The LHA allowance was frozen for four years in 2016 as part of the government’s austerity programme.

It comes after the Bureau of Investigative Journalism revealed that the majority of landlords in Britain would not rent properties to those on benefits.

Kate Henderson, chief executive of the NHF, told the Independent: ‘Low-income families in England are being punished two-fold.

Low income families are being ‘pushed to the brink’, because of the benefits freeze according to the NHF (Picture: Getty)

‘No longer able to access social housing because of the dire shortage of it, they now can’t access enough housing benefit to rent privately either.

‘The crippling effects of the housing crisis and significant cuts to benefits have forced thousands of parents into impossible situations in order to keep a roof over their children’s heads, many having to choose between crippling debt, overcrowding or homelessness.’

The worst places for affordability were in Huntingdon in Cambridgeshire, Thanet in Essex, and Stevenage in Hertfordshire.

They all had only one home within the budget of people on LHA.
